item.title: Black Sand | Ready to use apartments
item.description:
The Exchange Housing Complex intended for Pearl Horizon injured is about to receive the first residents. Macau Urban Renewal has announced that the six apartment blocks have already been licensed for use and that the next step will be to deliver the fractions to buyers
Almost 10 years later, part of the solution to one of the most intense real estate -related controversies in Macao is in sight, which involved cases in court, demonstrations and even applications to the Legislative Assembly. Pearl Horizon's injured buyers are about to occupy fractions in buildings built on the same terrain, this time under the aegis of Macau Urban Renewal (MRU). The public capital company announced that the housing project for exchange in the P Lot P of the new landfills, called Pearl Metropolitan, completed the inspection and licensing phase for use. According to MRU, the next step will be to advance with the delivery procedures of houses to buyers. The “Pearl Metropolitan is composed of six 50 -story apartment blocks, providing 2,064 autonomous fractions. At the end of March, the MRU indicated that from a total of 1,923 calls qualified to buy apartments in the complex, 1,880 had already chosen apartments. The company highlights the “superior geographical location” of the housing complex which, besides being next to the river, is close to access to the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau bridge, the Macao Bridge, the Qingmao borders and siege doors, as well as the Macao airport and the outdoor passenger maritime terminal. All included Each apartment block is equipped with four elevators. The parking lot has 1,873 seats for cars and 490 seats for motorcycles, equipped with electric vehicle recharge points. In addition, “Pearl Metropolitan” has Clubhouse, pool, gym and outdoor park, along an area with over 16,000 square meters. The recreation zone also has a playground and running route about 700 meters. The apartments are from the T1, T2 and T3 typology, with areas between 57 and 135 square meters, all have balconies and have all cooking and bathroom equipment. It is recalled that in the same lot are the residences for the elderly of the government, as well as the temporary housing for residents of the six IAO Hon-degraded public housing buildings that will be the subject of renewal. The building reserved for temporary housing, the UT Koi building, will also host the medical specialists of the islands Hospital who have no housing in the territory. The construction of Pearl Metropolitan began in 2021, and the housing complex was presented as a response to the needs of the injured buyers after a litigious process in which the government was the best in the courts to prosecutor Polytec. The granting of the land was declared invalid in January 2016, because the deadline for completing the construction, by the chief Chui Sai On. At the end of the judicial battle, the last court, at the time chaired by Sam Hou Fai, gave reason to the government.

item.title: Real Estate | Government accused of leaving sector “dying”
item.description:
The president of the Macao Real Estate Agents Association regrets that the government has ignored the situation of owners in the face of the devaluation of the real estate and that it has left the sector on the verge of extinction. Franky Fong suggests the elimination of notarial rates and taxes on real estate transactions
The president of the Macao Real Estate Real Estate Agents Association (official name), Franky Fong, is not satisfied with how the government has dealt with the sector crisis. Speaking to the newspaper or Mun, the representative lamented that, despite the "excellent results" of the game industry and the increase in the volume of tourists, "the government has ignored the real estate sector, which is in a dying state, as well as the owners affected by the devaluation of real estate, which made them poorest." From the perspective of the leader and businessman in the field, the government could take several measures to reverse the situation. To begin with, the SAM Hou Fai Executive could change the law that regulates the real estate mediation activity, updating or eliminating excessive penalties and costly regulations. Franky Fong argues that the law should have a penalty mechanism that applies fines and other penalties according to the severity of the offenses, so that agents have more opportunities to correct light failures. Make way Another way to stimulate the real estate sector, may undergo tax reduction, such as seal on the transmission of property and building contribution, and the weight of expenses, such as notarial charges, associated with the purchase and sale of real estate. Franky Fong does not agree that notarial charges are calculated according to the value of the property transaction, instead of having a fixed fee, as it turns out in Hong Kong where notarial and registration costs can range from a few hundred Hong Kong dollars, he said. Regarding fiscal policy, the official argues that only fractions inhabited under the lease agreement are subject to the collection of a building contribution. On the other hand, the associative leader advocates the facilitation of bank loans for home purchase, namely by reducing the entrance ratio, or through credit plans with bonuses. Currently, the maximum mortgage loan ratio is 70 percent and the amount of 30 percent of the house price. Franky Fong points out that both in Hong Kong and the interior of China, flexibility measures have been applied that allow the acquisition of housing without such a high capital entrance. For the associative leader, the return of the Macao residence fixation policy by investment would be another measure of capacity to inject new energy and capital in the market and the local economy.

item.title: Economy | Beijing will issue 6 billion debt in Macau
item.description:
The use of Macau as a platform to finance has been one of the central government's strategies to support the diversification of the local economy and promote the development of the field of finance
China will issue national obligations in Macao, worth 6 billion Yuan, to “support the development of the obligation of the obligation” of the MSAR, was announced yesterday. "The Ministry of Finance of the Government of the Popular Republic of China and the Government of the Special Administrative Region of Macao today announced [yesterday] that the central government will issue national obligations in Macao, worth six billion RMB [Renminbis]," can be read in a statement of the media. The issue, intended for institutional investors, will be made on July 16, adds the office. "Continuous issuance of national obligations in Macao demonstrates the importance and support of the central government regarding the cultivation of the new areas of financial activities in Macau, such as the obligationary market, and the promotion of diversified development of the economy of Macao," says the government of Raem, which greeted the decision of finances in Beijing. The emission “will help attract international investors to participate in the Macao's obligationary market, promote the development of the Offshore market from RMB in Macao and will deepen the financial cooperation between the interior of China and Macau,” he was added. Repeated Acts In October, China had already issued Macao debt securities worth 5 billion Yuan. The Macao government has mentioned the possible creation of a 'offshore' stock market, called Renminbi, linked to the role that the region has taken as a platform for commercial and financial services between China and Portuguese -speaking countries. In January, Macau's financial regulator said the central banks of Angola and Timor -Leste are interested in issuing public debt on the MSAR to attract investors from mainland China. Henrietta Lau Hang Kun, a member of the Board of the Monetary Authority of Macao, said the institution has been trying to promote the territory as "a financial service platform with Lusophone countries." "For now, we are still negotiating with Lusophone countries" so that the debt issuance "passes here, through Macao, to the [China] market," added Henrietta Lau. In May 2019, Portugal became the first country in the eurozone to issue debt in Chinese currency, worth 2 billion Renminbis.

item.title: AL | New Regiment prohibits deputies from disseminating content of the commissions
item.description:
With the new Hemiciclo Regiment approved yesterday, the deputies are prohibited from publicizing the subjects discussed in the meetings of the permanent committees, except for their presidents and secretaries. The subject generated debate yesterday in the Assembly regarding the limits of what may or may not be said. Pereira Coutinho voted against this article
The deputies of the Legislative Assembly (AL) are now prohibited from disseminating what is discussed at the Hemiciclo Commission meetings, "anyway," with the exception of its president and secretary. These usually disclose the content of the meetings at a press conference after their holding, and this will keep up. This new regulation arises after the vote and discussion, in general and specialty, the alteration to the al. It was one of the most discussed topics in yesterday's debate, with the deputies arguing on what may or can not be said, having José Pereira Coutinho voted against this concrete article. The disclosure of information from the meetings, which serves to analyze in the specialty proposals of law and always steering at the closed door, was something that was not yet regulated. Coutinho began by asking if he could disclose the information "during the plenary meeting", for example, having said that "he never heard of any deputy who had violated that duty." "There have been meetings in the past where the secretaries warned about the information that should not be disclosed and nothing has been said. We are only 33 deputies and we should think of the possibility of revealing what was discussed, because it is difficult to define borders about what can or can not be revealed and this will give rise to many discussions later," he said. The legislator also pointed out that "it can be difficult to execute this norm" and that "the principle of transparency" should be followed. Ho Ion Sang, who presided over to the commission that analyzed the new Al Regiment, explained that "the content of the meetings is subject to the duty of confidentiality and this matter was clarified." "The content can be said by the president of the commissions after the meetings, at the press conferences, and journalists can ask questions. In practice remains as always happened and that has given good results," he said. Meet the meetings Another point addressed, whether or not the permanent committees were held at the closed door, and Pereira Coutinho defended the opening to the public like what happens in Hong Kong. The AL regiment does not prohibit open meetings, but this always depends on a prior deliberation. But Iau Teng Pio, deputy, advised against the opening of the meetings. "The purpose of the closed -door meetings is so that members of the government, advisors and deputies can argue at ease even if there is no final decision. Kou Hoi In, president of AL, recalled that “the spirit of the norm has not been changed” and that everything will remain in it, only the ban on what deputies cannot refer outside the commissions. "The reserved character of permanent commissions is so that everyone can speak freely and if any deputy says this or that can spoil sensations of injustice in society to deputies and this cannot happen. We have to protect deputies and ensure confidentiality." At yesterday's meeting, there was also the discussion of the duty of the deputy to participate in all permanent committees, even in those to which he does not belong. Several deputies spoke of the need for better coordination of meetings agendas. "In the future there may be more practical coordination because there are many meetings and law proposals. We can schedule the meetings for more deputies," he said. Moreover, the new Al regiment prohibits deputies by "clothing or signs, banners, signs or other objects that have offensive content or political provocation, or undermine the dignity of the AL".

item.title: HALFTONE | New issue of the magazine presented today at FRC
item.description: Halftone - Macau Photography Association today presents, from 6.30 pm, at the Rui Cunha Foundation, the 12th edition of its magazine Halftone, a publication dedicated to photography. The new number has six visual projects, two of them black and white, which open and close the magazine. Jane Xu's first, who is entitled “Black Enlivened by Colors”, offers a portrait of female intimacy, in line with the artist's visual practice and his thematic research. In a different way, but still black and white, João Palla concludes in this number of the magazine the second part of his project “White Gold Whispers”. “The poetic expression of its visual proposal articulates perfectly with the aesthetic effect obtained with the contrast between black and white,” says the event organization The four other visual projects, in color, test different approaches to chromatic and thematic composition. Jorge Veiga Alves presents “Memories of Macau”, seeking to reinforce the memory effect in the approach to the contemplation of traditional spaces, namely religious in nature. Field and city José Luís de Sales Marques' second color project is dedicated to the famous procession of Senhor dos Passos, which takes place in Macao, underlining the role of this event, not only in the social and cultural context of the city, but also in its integration into the public space of Macau. In the third project, António Duarte Mil-Homens presents us a contemplative time in “Sunset, Moonrise”, addressing the nature and essence of the Alentejo landscape. The succession of color marks the hours and differentiates impressions, which conform the immensity of the Alentejo plain and its morphology. In the fourth project, color also plays a key role in its expressiveness and visual conformation: Tang Kuok Hou's “photosynthesis” proposes a social and aesthetic exploitation of the city of Macao, reinforcing its role as a place of photographic study par excellence, which has justified a multitude of various approaches, both thematic and sociological or formal, given its expressive richness.

item.title: EU | China rejects interference in the relationship with Russia
item.description: The Chinese government yesterday rejected interference with its relations with Russia, after the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, appealed to Beijing to end his “unshakable support” to Moscow in the war against Ukraine. "Normal cooperation between China and Russia does not admit interference from third parties," Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Mao Ning said at a press conference. Mao assured that the ties between Beijing and Moscow "are not directed against any third part." The statements arise in response to criticism from von der Leyen, who said the day before, during a debate in the European parliament, that "the unshakable support of China to Russia is creating great instability and insecurity for Europe." "We can say that, in practice, China is allowing Russia's war economy - and this is not acceptable," said the leader of the community executive, stressing that the way Beijing continues to interact with the Vladimir Putin war will be determining for the future of relations between the European Union (EU) and China. Von der Leyen is expected to visit Beijing in late July, accompanied by European Council Chairman António Costa for a summit who will mark the 50 years of diplomatic relations between the two parties.

item.title: PAULO MAIA AND CARMO
item.description: Wang Qia, the painter of the Tang Dynasty (618-906), would be remembered as creator of a 'school' of designated painting, 'scattered ink' that valued the spontaneous gesture of brush to make visible something that is naturally invisible. A mode of representation that sought communication between the author's spirit and that of the invited observer to discern the purpose of creation through the exposure of the process. A demanding discipline, recognized until centuries later by distinguished theoreticals such as Dong Qichang (1555-1635), which put the barrier from which this painting could be exercised very high: no less than in Wang Wei (701-61) mode, the recognized founder of literate painting: 'Only after someone is like Wang Wei can use the Wang Qia Pomo way'. Examples from the brush of this creator are today hardly observable and the termination of it preserved, there is almost only the seductive echo of a name that refers the listener to the expression of the substance of the Spirit. However, there is another name that in the stories of painting is often associated with him, that of Gu Kuang (727-821), of whom the paintings today are also rare but from whom they have been stored poems that indicate an imponderable presence. In a palace poem, it is noted the availability to feel the abundant but subtle torrent of beauty captured by the senses, like the one in the wind or in a sound: «In a tower of jade, halfway to the sky, a song blown to the flute begins,/ The wind delivers in the palace the harmonious sound of the Palreo and the laughter of the girls who dwell. Drinking in the clepsidra,/ the waters, redrillants as crystals, would say a curtain unfolded over the Rio do Autumn. » But the poet and painter, disillusioned with the intrigues that embarrassed his duties at the service of the palace, removes the public service and will use the name well daoist buweng, the "old reclusive". Gu Kuang had obtained the Jinshi degree, which allowed him to be an imperial employee in 757, in the unstable time of Emperor Tang Suzong, whose reign (756-62) would be marked by the concern to calm the revolt of An Lushan who had spread like a forest fire. Revolt that had forced his father to abdicate, Emperor Xuanzong and the consequent condemnation of the death of his favorite concubine, a fact reported in Ba Juyi's plangent poem (722-846), corner of perpetual remorse. Born in Yunyang (current Danyang, Jiangsu) after a life saddened by the death of a son, he moves with his family in 792 to the mountainous chain of Maoshan, south of Jurong, where he will receive the grace of a new son at the age of seventy. The goat hair (HAO) brushes (HAO) are soft and serve to write small characters, rabbit hair are hard and those of the fingernail are between the two, with great elasticity for the handwriting of large characters. Sometimes a mixture of different hair is made, using those of other animals. There are brushes of all kinds of sizes, serving some to paint and others to call. The best for Chinese handwriting are the rabbit and goat hair mix. HU brushes were widely used in the imperial court. In the other part of the museum is the painter's room Zhao Mengfu with its utensils and some works, where the recorded stones are not lacking. item.title: About 97 percent of Spanish adolescents victim of sexual aggression on the internet
item.description: About 97 percent of teenagers in Spain is the victim of some kind of sexual violence on the internet, warned yesterday the Save the Children Non-Governmental Organization (NGO). The NGO released a report yesterday with the title “Networks that hold. Sexual exploitation of childhood and adolescence in digital environments”, which elaborated with the European Association for Digital Transition and which includes official data and an inquiry to over 1,000 young people aged 18 to 21. According to the study, 97 percent of these young people said they were victims of some kind of sexual violence on the Internet during adolescence, including contacts from adults for sexual purposes, unauthorized diffusion of intimate images or blackmail and threats to send intimate and sexual content. Another type of violence enhanced in the report is the use of artificial intelligence tools to create sexual content from a real image of adolescents or children (content known as 'Deepfake' or 'Ultra counterfeits'). According to the study, one in five young Spaniards was the victim of the creation and diffusion of these 'Deepfake' during adolescence, namely with sharing by another person, to third parties, and without consent, of their own nudity images, elaborated through artificial intelligence. "The Internet, social networks and technologies not only facilitate capture and exposure to sexual exploitation -related risks, but can be the means by which these violence against boys and girls are committed and allow their perpetuation," said Save the Children, in a statement released from the study published yesterday. Starter Social networks are the most frequent way for aggressors to start contacts with the teenage victims, with the study also highlighting online video games in the case of boys. After this first contact, they move to applications and messages of messages such as WhatsApp, Telegram or Discord. Girls are the ones that most denounce to be pressured to send intimate content (28.5 percent of 18.4 percent of boys), with the study that all victims had shared personal or intimate information on the Internet during childhood and adolescence. According to the study, only 50 percent of young people when they were smaller considered contact with unknown people one of the main risks of the internet and only 32.9 percent mentioned as dangerous the consented send of intimate images to adults. On the other hand, 70 percent states that it has not seen as a risk, in adolescence, the manipulation of photographs and videos with artificial intelligence. Asked the reasons why they sent intimate or sexual images of themselves, 48 ​​percent says it did not know it was something potentially dangerous, 46 percent weighed that it was normal and 42 percent sought attention, affection or some kind of validation. Alone at home In this context, Save the Children warns, in the study, for the lack of follow -up of minors; The scarce digital formation, in cybersecurity, privacy and recognition of danger situations and the intensive use of technologies by children and adolescents. According to data from the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Spain, cited in the NGO report, in 2023 there were 4,896 complaints for offenses on the Internet against children and adolescents, 1,068 of which were sexual crimes. "These numbers represent only the tip of the iceberg, as most cases do not know, in part, for the absence of denunciation and, in part, for the difficulties in detection, which increases when these facts take place in an online environment," said Save The Children Catalina Perazzo, cited in the NGO statement.

item.description:
Since Saturday, leaders of the countries that are part of the BRICS Group have been gathered in Rio de Janeiro for another summit designed to think about the reform of institutions and inclusion of more emerging economies, as well as the fight against Trump's rates. Highlight for the absences of Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin
Since Saturday, Rio de Janeiro hosts the BRICS Group leaders, which ends today. The first day was based on the dialogue around the ambition of emerging economies to reform international institutions and the defense of multilateralism. "I think the main message is this: at the time of so many international crises, conflicts, we are experiencing a succession of conflicts that only increase from year to year, having a set of countries reaffirming the power of diplomacy, cooperation, the need to act jointly, to solve the problems of the population and not to generate more destruction, such as conflicts, it is an opportunity that we always have to take advantage of," Lyrio, guide of discussions and agreements of heads of state at the conference, designated by the Brazilian presidency of the BRICS. In all, about 30 countries and nine international organizations have been present, with the Brazilian head of state, Lula da Silva leading the meeting, which has Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, South African President Cyril Ramaphosa, Angola President and African Union, the Secretary-General of United Nations, António Guterres, among others. The main absences are Russian and Chinese heads of state, two BRICS founding countries. Vladimir Putin, the target of a warrant of detention issued by the International Criminal Court (ICC), on suspicion of illegal deportation of Ukrainian children to Russia, will only participate in video conferencing. Chinese Prime Minister Li Qiang and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov will be the representatives of the two founding countries of the group, which represents more than 40 percent of the global population and more than 35 percent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) worldwide. From China with Love According to Chinese state agency Xinhua, Chinese prime minister promised to “expand cooperation with Brazil” in the areas of “digital and aerospace economy”. Li Qiang spoke on Saturday, as part of a meeting with Lula da Silva, noting that the country intends to “work with Brazil to take advantage of each other and expand cooperation in areas such as digital economy, green economy, scientific and technological and aerospace innovation”. Xinhua quotes words from Li Qiang, who referred to the fact that “China is ready to work with Brazil to continue efforts to enrich the dimensions of bilateral relations and achieve more concrete results in cooperation in order to provide more benefits to both peoples”. One of the points out of this meeting was the realization in 2026 of the year of China-Brazil culture, which provides for an intensification in cooperation in areas such as “education, youth and health”, in order to facilitate “more exchanges between peoples and strengthen public support to China-Brazil's friendship and cooperation”. “China is willing to work with Brazil to further consolidate and deepen bilateral cooperation in trade, finance and infrastructure development within the high quality cooperation of Belt And Road [track and route]”, the Chinese prime minister, who did not forget the great flag of this BRICS Summit: multilateralism. Thus, I read Qiang considered “the two countries as fierce defenders of multilateralism and free trade”, saying that “China is willing to improve communication and coordination with Brazil in multilateral structures such as the United Nations, BRICS and G20, work in union with developing countries to promote an equal and ordered multipolar world and universally beneficial and inclusive economic globalization, and provide more certainty and stability to the world. ” On the other hand, Lula da Silva said that "Brazil is willing to deepen communication and multilateral coordination with China, to oppose unilateralism and defend multilateralism and free trade in order to promote peace and world development." After the meeting between the two leaders, “cooperation documents in areas such as tax and financial matters, artificial intelligence, alignment of development strategies and aerospace” were signed.
Cuba's debut Cuba President Miguel Díaz-Canel also participates in the 17th BRICS Summit, being the first time Cuba has associated with this geopolitical and economic cooperation group. Under the motto “reinforcing cooperation in the global south for more inclusive and sustainable governance”, the BRICS Summit's agenda comprises two central axes: the consolidation of cooperation between the global southern countries and the promotion of reforms in international governance mechanisms. Created in 2009 throughout Brazil, Russia, India and China, BRICS admitted South Africa two years later and, since last year, integrates six new effective members: Egypt, United Arab Emirates, Ethiopia, Iran, Indonesia and Saudi Arabia. Brazil invited to this summit leaders from various Latin American countries, including Mexico, Colombia, Uruguay and Chile. The statute of associate, which takes Cuba to Rio de Janeiro, was approved in October 2024 during the summit of the group held in the Russian city of Kazan, which was made official in 2025, recalled the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Caribbean country. In addition to geopolitical issues, BRICS have sought in Rio de Janeiro in the organization's economic weight, namely in the financial domain, in which they have been looking for a dollar for years for trade in the group. The host president, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, president of Brazil, stressed last Friday the importance of a mechanism with these characteristics, recognizing, however, that the current international political context is "complicated". What is on the agenda On the first day, the heads of state and government of the BRICS participated in two plenary sessions, particularly on "peace and security and reform of global governance" and the second relative to the strengthening of multilateralism, economic and financial affairs and artificial intelligence. " In the latter, the revision of the ACCIORARY participation in the World Bank, the realignment of IMF shares [International Monetary Fund] and the increase in the representation of developing countries in leadership positions in international financial institutions and the importance of reforming the UN Security Council. In addition, as it has been happening during the BRICS ministerial meetings over the past few months, an increase in unilateral unilateral unilateral protectionist measures should be made in reference to the measures announced by the President of the United States, Donald Trump; as well as an appeal to reinforce the use of local currencies in trade between the bloc countries. Today the plenary session will be on “Environment, COP30 and Global Health”. The term BRIC was created by a Goldman Sachs analyst to refer to emerging economies who began to stand out worldwide beyond the US, and the BRICS first gathered at the level of heads in 2009. This is the first meeting that brings together the new group configuration with 11 member countries. Brazil has mobilized about 20,000 military personnel, as well as fighters with missiles, anti-drug systems and elite shooters to ensure the safety of the event. The safety operation, called Operational Command Redeemer Set, also provides for the use of 300 vehicles, 38 armored vehicles, 18 boats and eight helicopters.

The disclosure of information from the meetings, which serves to analyze in the specialty proposals of law and always steering at the closed door, was something that was not yet regulated. Coutinho began by asking if he could disclose the information "during the plenary meeting", for example, having said that "he never heard of any deputy who had violated that duty." "There have been meetings in the past where the secretaries warned about the information that should not be disclosed and nothing has been said. We are only 33 deputies and we should think of the possibility of revealing what was discussed, because it is difficult to define borders about what can or can not be revealed and this will give rise to many discussions later," he said. The legislator also pointed out that "it can be difficult to execute this norm" and that "the principle of transparency" should be followed. Ho Ion Sang, who presided over to the commission that analyzed the new Al Regiment, explained that "the content of the meetings is subject to the duty of confidentiality and this matter was clarified." "The content can be said by the president of the commissions after the meetings, at the press conferences, and journalists can ask questions. In practice remains as always happened and that has given good results," he said. Meet the meetings Another point addressed, whether or not the permanent committees were held at the closed door, and Pereira Coutinho defended the opening to the public like what happens in Hong Kong. The AL regiment does not prohibit open meetings, but this always depends on a prior deliberation. But Iau Teng Pio, deputy, advised against the opening of the meetings. "The purpose of the closed -door meetings is so that members of the government, advisors and deputies can argue at ease even if there is no final decision. Kou Hoi In, president of AL, recalled that “the spirit of the norm has not been changed” and that everything will remain in it, only the ban on what deputies cannot refer outside the commissions. "The reserved character of permanent commissions is so that everyone can speak freely and if any deputy says this or that can spoil sensations of injustice in society to deputies and this cannot happen. We have to protect deputies and ensure confidentiality." At yesterday's meeting, there was also the discussion of the duty of the deputy to participate in all permanent committees, even in those to which he does not belong. Several deputies spoke of the need for better coordination of meetings agendas. "In the future there may be more practical coordination because there are many meetings and law proposals. We can schedule the meetings for more deputies," he said. Moreover, the new Al regiment prohibits deputies by "clothing or signs, banners, signs or other objects that have offensive content or political provocation, or undermine the dignity of the AL".

item.title: Cape Verde | Évora family, between Macau and the rest of the world
item.description:
Tomorrow are 50 years of Cape Verde's independence, the country from which the first levada of the Évora family came out in the 1940s, towards Macao, where he won roots. Nowadays, only one member of the family remains in the territory, the cardiologist Mário Évora
There were once a dozen Évoras in Macao, where they arrived in the 1940s, but only Mario Évora resists, with the family repeating the migrations that mark both Cape Verde and the Macanese. "We have been between eight and ten Évoras in Macau," Sports Medicine expert Humberto Évora told Lusa from Lisbon, where he has lived since he renovated. The maternal grandparents of Humberto (the last of the family to be born in Cape Verde) and Mário (the first to be born in Macau) arrived in the east in the late 1940s, with five of the couple's six children. A year later, the daughter who had stayed with her husband in Cape Verde came to Macau, already with baby Humberto. The initial plan was for two years, but the couple ended up three decades and have three more children: Mario, Rui and Maria Helena. In 1971, it was the turn of Humberto and Mário to leave to study medicine in Lisbon, but not without a great fright linked to the colonial war that had lasted a decade ago. "As we went to the university we could postpone military inspection, but the papers did not come from Macao and we risk being considered refractory," said Humberto. The situation resolved, but Mario admitted to Lusa the fear of the mobilization. "We had this persecution, we had to go through the year not to go with the sides in the war," he explained. “The Shock” in Lisbon Upon arrival in Lisbon, “we were soon welcomed and integrated into the Cape Verdean student community,” said Humberto, at a time of student agitation and politics. "There were periods when it was almost daily, manifestations of students against the regime, the shock police enter the canteen inside and give some suckling," said Mario. Humberto admitted that "it was a shock, for those who came from Macau, where there was little political culture and the colonial war was seen as a struggle against terrorists." In a summer, the young man, who was integrated into a Cape Verdean group of intervention music, left with a friend "to the overseas ride out of guitar on his back." “I always remember the first time in France, that I saw the colonial war described on the contrary on television, the struggle for the liberation of a colonial power of occupation,” said Humberto. Independence When the two brothers finished the medical course, the independence of Cape Verde, on July 5, 1975, led them to the root return. "There was a movement of many of our colleagues to contribute to a new country, which was beginning to take the first steps," said Mario, then a formed cardiologist. Also because, recalled Humberto, some of the friends of Lisbon had, however, became members of the Government of Cape Verde. "There was this possibility, but the return to Macao, a place where it had spent so long, was natural," he explained. “I was born in Cape Verde, I spent part of my life in Portugal, I grew up in Macao, I am also Macaense. I am a citizen of the world,” said Humberto. Macanese are a Euro-Asian community, most of which Lusodescendants, with roots in Macau, although many have emigrated, due to the economic situation or fear created by the transition from Portugal Administration to China in 1999. From the Évora brothers, Rui, engineer, left before the transition to Cape Verde, where he even worked on the project of the Hotel-Casino that Macau's businessman David Chow built on the beach, but was inaugurated. The younger sister, Maria Helena, expert in documentary sciences who even worked in the historical archive of Macau, is currently in the City Council of Oeiras. The children “are all out” between the United Kingdom, Cape Verde and Portugal, said Mario. "Now the world is smaller and it is going where there are opportunities," he said. Humberto also faces migrations "as a natural process, not only for Cape Verdeans, but even to the Macanese." Nothing that has prevented the two brothers from keeping their ties with the archipelago. Humberto divides the time between Portugal and Cape Verde, and has been the official doctor of Cape Verdean sports for decades to the main international competitions. Mario was one of the founders-and president for ten years-of the Macau-Cabo Green Friendship Association. "We had here Ildo Lobo, Tito Paris, and my cousin," said the cardiologist, before taking a break and adds, with a smile: "Cesaria Évora."

item.title: WHO | Study reveals that one in six people in the world feels
item.description:
A World Health Organization report states that loneliness is a growing problem. Based on a study conducted between 2014 and 2023, the document concluded that one in six people in the world feel alone, with emphasis on young people from 13 to 29 years old. The Southeast Asian region has, however, less problematic values
More and more is spoken of the devastating impact of loneliness as a potentializing cause of diseases. This time, a report from the World Health Organization (WHO), released on Monday and carried out by the Social Connection Commission, brings data on the problem, concluding that one in six people say he feels alone, a state that is not synonymous with being alone. Moreover, the problem is greater in younger ones, because one in five says it feels alone, which shows that one fifth of the world's population between 13 and 29 years old says it feels loneliness. The study, entitled “From Solitude to Social Connection - tracing a path to healthier societies: WHO Commission on Social Connection Commission”, focuses on 2013 and 2024, thus encompassing the pandemic, a period when most of the world populations faced confinement periods, some of them alone in their dwellings. The study was sent to journalists from 194 WHO member countries, and the data were dealt with in line with other works already done on the subject and with the support of experts from around the world, including from China. Bin Yu, from the Medical College Tianjin University, was one of the project participants. The report points out that between 2014 and 2023 "it is estimated that 16 percent of people around the world-one in six-felt loneliness," something that "affects all ages and regions." However, it is a “more common feeling among adolescents and young adults”, with a rate of 20.9 percent of young people between 13 and 17 years old, while the rate reduces slightly to 17.4 percent in the case of young adults from 18 to 29 years. The feeling of loneliness "decreases with age", and is also "more common in low-income countries, where almost one in four people (24 percent) claimed to feel lonely." The WHO study also points out that “the highest rates are in the WHO African region”, with 24 percent; Following the regions of the Eastern Mediterranean (21 percent), and in Southeast Asia this feeling is less felt by respondents, registering only 18 percent. "The European region has the lowest rate, with about ten percent," says WHO, which distinguishes loneliness of social isolation. In this field, “data is more limited”, but the isolation of the elderly stands out. "Estimates suggest that 25-34 percent of the elderly are socially isolated," it is data on the years between 1990 and 2022. When it comes to adulthood, from 30 to 59 years, the percentage of people who feel only low to 15.1 percent, and in people 60 years or older, with 11.8 percent. Regarding gender, “estimated rates of loneliness in women and men are similar (16.1 and 15.4 percent, respectively), with the highest estimated differences between adolescents (24.3 percent between women and 17.2 percent between men) and the elderly (13 percent between women and 9.9 percent among men)”. Who else feels The report states that nowadays “social disconnection is widespread in all regions and in all age groups”, with consequences that are “serious and underestimated, affecting mortality, physical and mental health, well-being, education, economy and society in general”. "Its widespread occurrence and its serious consequences make it a serious issue of global public health," it is mentioned. And who feels more alone? The WHO highlights “marginalized groups”, namely “people with disabilities, lesbians, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer (or sometimes in question) and other individuals (LGBTIQ+) and migrants”. These people “are more likely to feel loneliness and isolation than other groups”, making it the caveat that “previous data are too limited to determine whether social isolation and solitude rates have increased or decreased”. In the case of disabled people, scenarios persist such as being unable to “access social facilities and take advantage of opportunities due to physical barriers in buildings, limited access to transportation and lack of affordable information and communication, while others face structural stigma that limits their job opportunities or other sociocultural barriers that lead to lower level of education, less stable relationships and more precarious housing conditions”. "Many factors" are identified that lead people to feel alone, namely "modernization, industrialization and technological changes", and may be "responsible for what, often, it is presumed to be an increase in social isolation and loneliness, but most remain without proof." "We know that certain factors increase the risk of individuals suffering from social disconnection. These include poor physical or mental health (especially depression), personality traits such as neuroticism, not having a partner or being single, living alone and characteristics of the built environment, such as poor access to public transport. The impact of digital technology is not yet clear, but experts recommend caution, especially to protect the mental health and well-being of young people." study. The WHO highlights, throughout the text, how it is difficult to quantify feelings of loneliness, being relatively recent this type of definitions and, above all, differentiation between the feeling of feeling alone and being effectively only. The report includes testimonies from people from various countries and cultures that describe that, even though they are with a partner or friends, they feel alone in a scenario caused by many factors. In the case of young people, "the finding of high loneliness rates between adolescents is consistent with the results of previous research, although the result may be subject to both developmental and methodological considerations." “As loneliness results from a perceived discrepancy between real and desired or expected social connections, the highest rate in adolescence can be due to higher expectations of social connections during the development phase, which is marked by significant emotional and psychological changes. The elderly report a comparatively greater satisfaction with their social relations. According to these estimates, the elderly have the lower rates of loneliness, the elderly. which contradicts previous studies that enhanced the elderly as the age range with some of the highest rates. This may be due to the limited availability and quality of the previous data on the elderly, ”is explained. The study highlights, however, that it is “possible that the prevalence of loneliness is greater among adults over 80 or older”, which is a “consistent conclusion with previous studies, in which there was a distribution in the form of 'U' of loneliness among older adults”. More than 800 thousand deaths We are in an era where so -called social health is at risk, being considered by WHO as "a vital but often neglected, health, as essential as physical and mental health." "Social relations can reduce the risk of disease, increase life expectancy and strengthen the fabric of communities and society. Social relations improve life, giving us meaning and a feeling of belonging," it is also read, being mentioned that today loneliness affects one in six people worldwide and causes "about 871,000 deaths annually (2014-2019)". "New estimates suggest that loneliness alone may be responsible for about 871,000 deaths a year. The economic cost of these comprehensive impacts on society is just starting to be understood. Estimates suggest substantial costs for employers, health systems and individuals. Stronger social connections provide important protection in health, social and economic domains," he reads. The report points out that many of these issues only now begin to be perceived and analyzed. "This has probably been happening for years, but the pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the growing concern for digital technology has brought more attention to the issue, including governments," he is explained. The WHO also points to a correlation between poverty or low income and the feeling of loneliness. "In general, the lower the performance group in a country, the higher the loneliness rate. It is estimated that low-yielding countries have the higher (24.3 percent), followed by the medium-low yield countries (19.3 percent), medium-high performance countries (12.1 percent) and high-performance countries (10.6 percent)," can be read. Despite some worrying scenarios, WHO leaves some suggestions and even says that "there is hope" to get around the problem. "There are effective strategies for promoting social connection and these must be expanded," for example, by the "regular monitoring of the prevalence of social connection, social isolation and solitude at the global, regional and national level." This monitoring should be viewed as "a high priority", allowing "to track progress and measure the impact of strategies to deal with the issue." It is also suggested the “international development and adoption of reliable measuring instruments, interculturally valid for social connection, social isolation and loneliness”, and as a priority ”should be viewed the creation“ of an instrument to measure social connection, as conceived in this report: in the three dimensions of structure, function and quality ”. The study was based on reference documents on global and regional estimates of the prevalence of loneliness and mortality due to loneliness, “the first of this type”; a global review of political documents; Network mapping and analysis, the inclusion of 64 experiences experienced by people in relation to social connection, social isolation and loneliness, as well as “high quality evidence, prioritizing systematic revisions, meta-analysis and large-scale multinational studies”, without forgetting the experience of the WHO technical advisory group itself, “composed of 20 renowned global experts”.

item.title: China-Portuguese | Chengdu Pavilion shows Portuguese products
item.description:
In the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion venture in Chengdu, pavilions for foreign countries and entrepreneurs who want to establish business in China are installed. Portugal is also there, represented by the Portugal Pavilion, but according to manager Ângelo Sousa, there is a lack of support from the Portuguese government and strength to combat competition
“For us there are no barriers between Portugal and China. We are 365 days here and there.” This is the way the objectives of the team that is behind the Portugal Pavilion present at the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion are presented in Chengdu and which is managed by two partners: Yinhui Tui and Ângelo Freitas de Sousa. The two realized that the Shanghai zone had reached a saturation point in the trade of products and that it was necessary to go more to the interior of the country to try to sell things as Portuguese as wine, cod or olive oil. HM talked to Yinhui Tui about this project on the fringes of a lunch in Lisbon by the Friends of the New Seda Route Association, chaired by Fernanda Ilhéu. The event served precisely for Yinhui Tui to present the objectives of the Portugal Pavilion and try to capture business interests. “This is a very important market for Portuguese products. In China we have separated the country [in commercial terms] in four markets. We have the region of Beijing and Shanghai, which we call 'Yangtze River Economic Zone', and 'Pearl River Economic Zone'. The fourth zone is composed by the cities of Chengdu and Chongqing and which is a new economic area established in 2020. Portuguese have a lot of potential in these markets, ”he said. The entrepreneur recalls that the marketing of Portuguese products is still below the one that is done by French, Spanish or other countries, but when the Chinese buyer discovers wine or olive oil, he is surprised. "In Shanghai, for example, some customers already have their opinion on French or Australians. But many think that Portuguese products have more quality," said Yinhui Tui, noting that in the area where the Portugal Pavilion operates in Sichuan province, "people are a little more conservative and prefer to try, prove and feel before buying." "Our pavilion is next to the French pavilion and we often see customers opt for French wine. But when they go through our pavilion, they see our brands and ask what we have. When they realize that we have cheaper wine compared to French, they are surprised and say it is better, and then buy." This responsible explains that the population in the fourth economic zone is 130 million people, much more than the number of people living in the Iberian Peninsula. "Then I think it's a market with a lot of potential," he said. The Role of Lusosino Yinhui Tui and Ângelo Freitas de Sousa created Lusosino that it acts as the managing entity of the pavilion, which was born “with the intention of promoting Portuguese products in the Great Market of China”. Thus, there is a “showroom” of very Portuguese products, representing some brands known as is the case of Vieira crackers, Esporão wine, Sal Marnoto, the Prisca jams or Vista Alegre, among others. It is in this pavilion that "exhibitors display the best products, buyers discover trends and where they both find the conditions to realize business." Moreover, Lusosino, through this pavilion, helps Portuguese entrepreneurs in marketing campaigns and in the best way to contact potential Chinese customers. Specifically, Lusosino promises to perform “producer and brands records, commercial representation, market analysis, market support and preparation, among other services”, reads on the website. However, and according to Ângelo Freitas de Sousa to HM, there are many obstacles to putting Portuguese products in China. “[The Chengdu and Chongqing zone] has the advantage of being a growing market that is not overloaded with exporters and has no addictions as happens in the Shanghai zone. It is a very large market and where there are many producers.” By addictions, the entrepreneur refers to “competition” from other countries and buying habits of Chinese customers, who are faster looking for products from other nationalities than from Portugal. "There are habits of certain brands that are implemented and people don't even look at others or experience them." The Portuguese Pavilion project began with an idea of ​​Ângelo Ferreira de Sousa, who has a Chinese wife who helps him in the business. “I met Yinhui Tui, he liked Portuguese products, we were friends and then we ended up joining energy,” he said, explaining that the interior of the country is still knowing foreign products, not just Portuguese. "The Shanghai zone has nowhere to grow and this is a growing economic zone. There are many factories that are moving to Chengdu, so there will be more development," he said. Absence of marketing The Portuguese entrepreneur regrets that the Portuguese authorities have given little support to the project, except for any follow -up by AICEP - Agency for Investment and Foreign Trade of Portugal. "All the investment was made by us and we have not had a lot of support. We had some help from AICEP, but nothing special. We do fairs, the showrooms, to prove and know our products in major cities," said Angelo Ferreira de Sousa. The entrepreneur also regrets that, despite the relationship of hundreds of years between Portugal and China, there is still flaws in the commercial strategy for the export of Portuguese products in the country. "The Spaniards are much further ahead than us," he said. Regarding the role of Macao as a platform, the entrepreneur says it is equally difficult to bring products from Portugal to China or Macau to China, due to lack of customs agreements and little flexibility. "It is not because we call Macau that I can, for example, putting sausages, cod or preserves in China, or other Portuguese products. To pass from Portugal to Macau is easy, but it is no longer so easy to take after Portuguese products from Macau to China. We have not been able to do much through Macau, but we have not sought much," he said. At the presentation in Lisbon, Yinhui Tui advanced some figures behind the construction of the Euro-Asia National Commodity Pavillion, and help to understand their size: about 70 billion euros of investment and a space of 300,000 cubic meters. The Portugal Pavilion does not only do contact sessions or fairs: if a businessman wants to leave tons of products there, he can do so. Then the pavilion is in charge of distribution through several areas of China. “In the southern market, closer to Macao, there is a lot of competition in some areas, so it should be betting inside China,” said Yinhui Tui, referring to the potential and factor novelty that exists in some areas of the country regarding commerce.

item.title: Check | Will make distribution to the elderly and pensioners
item.description: The Institute of Social Action (IAS) will distribute the pecuniary reimbursement of 2025 to qualified residents to receive subsidies for the elderly and disability. According to the information indicated yesterday by IAS, the “qualified beneficiaries of the elderly allowance residing outside Macao and the qualified beneficiaries of the disability allowance” will receive the “check”, or the bank transfer, in July if the life proof has been completed until June 22. In case they have not taken the test of life until that date, IAS appeals to it “as soon as possible” to receive the check in the month following the life test. In addition to the distribution of the check, IAS says that “to manage the public purse and monitor the situation of the beneficiaries” will continue the “work to verify the beneficiaries of the elderly subsidy”.

item.title: Investment Funds | New Law rises to the Plenary of AL
item.description: The 2nd Permanent Commission of the Legislative Assembly ended the discussion of the Investment Funds Law yesterday that will now go to the Plenary to be voted in the specialty. According to Chan Chak Mo, quoted by the newspaper or Mun, the new law will introduce into the Macao planning “innovative legal concepts” such as the possibility of transferring to the territory funds existing in other jurisdictions. The deputy and president of the 2nd Permanent Committee of the Legislative Assembly also said he believed that the approval of the diploma will allow Macau to maintain the pace of international development, attract more funds and financial institutions and develop as a financial market. Chan Chan Mo also pointed out that the new law will follow international standards and allow greater protection to investors, which found it fundamental for them to consider Macau as a safe place to invest. In addition, future law is seen as a way to improve the internal regulation system and remove bureaucratic obstacles to the development of investment funds. The deputy argued that the law has a different regulation for public and private investment funds and follows examples of the interior, Hong Kong and Mountain Island. According to the information provided by the government to the deputies, there is currently only one investment fund in Macao, with a capital of about 200 million Renminbis. In addition, another request was filed to start a fund with an investment of 100 million Renminbis, which is being analyzed by the Monetary Authority of Macao.

item.title: Macau Foundation | André Ritchie at the Curators Council
item.description:

Wu Zhiliang's term as president of the Macau Foundation (FM) was renewed for a year, according to an order published yesterday in the official bulletin. At the council's council level, Sam Hou Fai promotes some changes, such as André Ritchie's entry, while his mother, Anabela Ritchie, is no longer part of the healer group. The president of FM will maintain a salary of about 103,400 patacas per month, having been ahead of the body since 2010. Also vice president Zhong Yi Seabra de Mascarenhas sees renewed confidence, despite the change of the chief executive since last year's appointment, and will earn a salary of about 90,240 monthly patacas. Sam Hou Fai also bet on the continuity of the Fiscal Council, by renewing the appointment of Vong Hin Fai as president. Also president of the Macao Lawyers Association will earn 19,740 Patacas per month for the performance of his duties at the Macau Foundation. Renewals also apply to Ho Va and Lau Veng Lin, which will have salaries of 16,450 monthly patacas. New faces Although the Board of Directors and the Fiscal Council do not change, the same did not happen with the Macau Foundation's curators Council. According to the information revealed yesterday, this Council and former Coordinator Cabinet for Transport Infrastructure, André Ritchie. On the contrary is his mother, Anabela Ritchie, the first woman to preside over to the Legislative Assembly, whose mandate was not renewed. Still at the level of exits, highlighting PUI LAM Law, former president of the Macao Education Association, which was replaced by Cheang Hong Kuong, who currently presides over the association. Also Lok PO, owner of the newspaper or Mun and former deputy of the National Popular Assembly, is outside the council council. Lok pou is replaced by Choi Chi Tou, chief of the same newspaper. The FM's curators' council aims to ensure the maintenance of the Foundation's ends, to consider the activities plan, the exercise report, the budget for the following year and the financial report for the previous year. In addition to these functions, it is also competent to approve the granting of financial support over one million patacas.

item.title: HMZ Bridge | Open Quota Renewal Period
item.description: Vehicle owners with quota vehicles to circulate on the Hong Kong-Macau-Zhuhai Bridge, issued in 2018 or 2019, can since yesterday to submit requests for renewal. The announcement was released through a statement from the Directorate of Service for Traffic Affairs (DSAT). Renewals have to be done within 90 days before the end of the quotas, through the DSAT online system. The renewal process has a cost of 1,000 patacas, and the money is not returned, even if the renewal is not guaranteed. Quotas holders covered by renewal do not need to maintain Hong Kong -related qualification that allowed them to have access to the quota. This means that the authorities will not see if individuals continue to work in Hong Kong, as required at the beginning, or if companies that had access to quotas maintain a subsidiary in Raehk. Quota renewals will have a period of three years. If the request for renewal is not submitted and the payment of 1,000 Patacas is not made until the date of expiration term of the quota, it will be considered lost and redistributed in a future competition.

item.title: Economy | Beijing will issue 6 billion debt in Macau
item.description:
The use of Macau as a platform to finance has been one of the central government's strategies to support the diversification of the local economy and promote the development of the field of finance
China will issue national obligations in Macao, worth 6 billion Yuan, to “support the development of the obligation of the obligation” of the MSAR, was announced yesterday. "The Ministry of Finance of the Government of the Popular Republic of China and the Government of the Special Administrative Region of Macao today announced [yesterday] that the central government will issue national obligations in Macao, worth six billion RMB [Renminbis]," can be read in a statement of the media. The issue, intended for institutional investors, will be made on July 16, adds the office. "Continuous issuance of national obligations in Macao demonstrates the importance and support of the central government regarding the cultivation of the new areas of financial activities in Macau, such as the obligationary market, and the promotion of diversified development of the economy of Macao," says the government of Raem, which greeted the decision of finances in Beijing. The emission “will help attract international investors to participate in the Macao's obligationary market, promote the development of the Offshore market from RMB in Macao and will deepen the financial cooperation between the interior of China and Macau,” he was added. Repeated Acts In October, China had already issued Macao debt securities worth 5 billion Yuan. The Macao government has mentioned the possible creation of a 'offshore' stock market, called Renminbi, linked to the role that the region has taken as a platform for commercial and financial services between China and Portuguese -speaking countries. In January, Macau's financial regulator said the central banks of Angola and Timor -Leste are interested in issuing public debt on the MSAR to attract investors from mainland China. Henrietta Lau Hang Kun, a member of the Board of the Monetary Authority of Macao, said the institution has been trying to promote the territory as "a financial service platform with Lusophone countries." "For now, we are still negotiating with Lusophone countries" so that the debt issuance "passes here, through Macao, to the [China] market," added Henrietta Lau. In May 2019, Portugal became the first country in the eurozone to issue debt in Chinese currency, worth 2 billion Renminbis.

item.title: National Games | Ron Lam regrets little participation of Macau
item.description: Deputy Ron Lam appealed yesterday to the period before the order of the debate day at AL to talk about Macau's little participation in some modalities on the occasion of the territory of the 15th edition of the National Games. The event includes 34 sports competition and 23 popular modalities, and guangdong, Hong Kong and Macau can participate. However, according to the deputy, on May 20, the Sports Institute (ID) “announced that Macao would only participate in 19 sports competitions and 12 modalities for the public, that is, in terms of proportion, corresponds to a participation rate of less than 60 percent of the modalities”. The deputy pointed out that "the government has not yet announced which modalities in which Macau will participate, wasting the unique opportunity of the population of Macau to participate in national events," unlike Hong Kong, which began in January this year "the selection process in 23 modalities for the public, with a view to allowing the registration of all qualified residents". “It is noteworthy that the modalities for the public are not for the participation of professional athletes. For example, the Badminton modality is divided into four age groups, from 25 to 64 years old. Does Macau have no participant who can participate in this modality?”, Asked the deputy, who suggests the creation of a “formal means for the registration of athletes interested in participating in national games and adopting uniform criteria, justice and transparent for the team selection that will represent Macau. ”

item.title: AL | New status of deputies voted in general
item.description: Yesterday the changes to a 2000 law related to the Legislature and the Statute of the Deputies to the Legislative Assembly (AL) was approved in general and which clarifies, among other matters, the loss of mandates. In his voting statement, Deputy Kou Kam Fai argued that these changes, proposed by a group of deputies, which includes the president of Hemiciclo, aim to “concretize the principle of Macao governed by Patriots”, which is a “necessary change for our legal system”. It is thus clarified which "deputies who are not faithful to the basic law, having been added a rule regarding the serious violation of duties." For Kou Kam Fai, the new statute will "ensure the right to defend the deputies and increase the dignity of the AL". Deputies Chan Chak Mo and Angela Leong have jointly stated that these changes allow “the most efficient functioning of the legislature, more clearly defining the responsibilities and duties of deputies”, ideas based on the guarantee of “state security”. Thus, “a more updated and enhanced legal framework,” added Angela Leong.

item.title: The door of the stars (III)
